comments.commentBody:
I am disgusted.

That's right, folks. Put on your blinders and follow the rabbit, nothing to see here. Keep your women and children out of this savage land. Put your money in the pot and you shall have salvation. Premium subscribers only, little people. :rolleyes:

If anyone is capable of reverting the internet to AOL, it's Murdoch and Apple. This times writer didn't give an opinion, only an observation of what is likely her Apple centric experience of tech. Poor, poor Virginia. Its time to put away those toys and witness real the power of the internet, where the people are free to express their views and functions may be *gasp* duplicated in a Darwinian attempt at improving efficiency, functionality, and the user experience. So much choice is intimating, I know, but sticking your head in the sand is not an appropriate response. Although you need to be cautious, you should never be [I]afraid[/I] of the internet.

Apple gave mobile development the HUGE jump start they needed, but our relatively free market isn't going to allow Apple to govern the web. It will take time, but public opinion of Apple will eliminate their stranglehold. There are 100,000 Android phones activated every day and while the Android is outselling the iPhone, it is only a matter of time before Android outnumbers all iPhone OS devices. Like when a religious zealot campaigns for public office, their followers will make such a ruckus we cannot hear anyone else. But on election day, when the votes are counted, the rational minds will have outnumber the excitable sheep and our institution will stay intact.

For someone that promotes the benefits self-publishing ( http://www.nytimes.com... ), I am sure she can comprehend the capabilities Murdoch and friends have to destroy this beautiful culmination of humanity.

Valor is not needed in an occupation.
http://emcphd.wordpress.com/

The family should accept the Navy Cross.

The Medal of Honor must have a level of equality across the generations and there is not enough information in the reporting as it does not provide the medical record.

Great job, Ms. Zoepf. I learned a good deal from reading your article. I can think of nothing else, that I observed this Memorial Day weekend, that honors our fallen soldiers more than your thoughts regarding this mans valour. The New York times will continue to be a great newspaper just as long as they have real journalist like yourself on their staff.
jjfisher

What happened to valor, as Sgt. Peralta's mother may well now be asking, after her son's heroic death.

But thousands of miles away,it might also be apropos for some concerned Filipinos to ask, what ever happened to HONOR?

Filipinos who voted for Noynoy Aquino hope that their lives will improve once he becomes president.

I doubt if this will happen.

I read foreign periodicals, and I read somewhere that a Filipino writer journalist was the author of the 1986 People Power Manifesto, which benefited Cory Aquino in 1986, and now her son, Noynoy.

Yet, I also read that, sadly, said intellectual never benefited from his act, nor merited even a pip or a squeak from the Cojuangco-Aquino clan.

If a simple gesture of a debt of gratitude, or a token act of kindness is dishonorable, is too much for the Cojuangco-Aquinos to extend, what gratitude can Filipinos expect from Noynoy now?

How disgusting it is that government bureaucracy has so deeply sullied the Pentagon. I have to ask myself if what they're saying is the Medal of Honor is for those who would voluntarily have an arm spasm and bring a grenade to their body to take out enemy combatants, and the Navy Cross, well, that's for the cognitively impaired who do it involuntarily.

I agree that it appears that actions that once would result in an award of the Medal of Honor seem no longer to do so.

I suggest that the Department of Defense set up for each request a board of military combat veterans. To this board, each Medal of Honor narrative would be submitted after verification, but with identifying information removed. With the request, two or three earlier recipients' narratives would also be submitted with identifying information removed. The narratives would not be marked with dates, nor would there be any way of knowing which narrative was the new one and which those of former recipients.

The board would be asked to judge whether the actions of all the narratives were consistent. If the board determined that all the narratives showed consistent levels of valor, the medal would be awarded.

If the criteria for the Medal of Honor have now become so high that it is impossible for a living combat veteran to receive it, we need to say so, and recognize the next level of award (Distinguished Service Cross, Navy Cross, Air Force Cross) as the modern equivalent.

As selfless and heroic an act of the Marine Sgt, it does not rise to the standard of a Medal of Honor. The MoH was designed for exceptional situations beyond reactionary and immediate responses to danger.

I seriously doubt that his ethnicity had any part in the decision. If anything the military looks for excuses to award commendations to its perceived minorities.

This man's death is tragic and his quick thinking to save his friends admirable. He deserves to be honored, just not this particular honor.

It is obvious that the leaders of today, lacking the courage to even tell the truth for fear of losing their positions of power and privilege, are incapable of recognizing heroism in others. When was the last time you heard a general or politician admit a mistake or risk their job (much less their life) for a principle?

Insanity!  A young man, little more than a boy, is dead--dead forever, you understand, he's not coming back--and a hunk of medal is offered as solace?  And there's a controversy about what kind---highest honor, second highest, way down near the bottom because he may not have been  sufficiently "brave?"  And people acually comment on the NYTimes site to regisster their opinions about this?  Why aren't they discussing the monstrous lies and cold-blooded machinations of our "leaders" who enticed the poor kid to enlist and provide fodder for this illegal and immoral war?  The real reason for the "honors" being so earnestly debated is to lure more young people into sacrificing their lives on the altar of American hubris.  Wilfred Owen called it "the old lie":  Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori ("It is sweet and honorable to die for one's country") and it is a lie.

The sad truth is that a pathologist who was not there, has probably never been in a firefight, and can not unequivocally say Peralta did or did not pull the grenade underneath him is being countenanced more than the fellow Marines who were there and his Chain of Command that investigated the case not once but twice. That is a travesty of honor and truth. In the weighing of evidence, eyewitness accounts should hold more than a technocrats sterile supposition of what happened. The facts are that Sgt Peralta shielded his fellow marines from a grenade, saving their lives and sacrificing his own. That is the highest hero that I know. Anything less than the Medal of Honor is an insult to him, his family, the Marines that served with him and the entire US Armed Forces. I have nothing but deep respect for his Mother. She was right to not accept the Navy Cross. It is now incumbent upon us to set this right.

"Other observers have suggested — and Petraeus’s comments to me could be seen to support the idea — that the military, after its recent experiences with Jessica Lynch and Pat Tillman, is hesitant to publicize or otherwise herald tales of heroism, for fear of later embarrassment."

If that's the case, and it seems believable that it could be, then make it like canonization - requiring a multi-year process so that there is time for the additional details to come out. That would be a better response than awarding only 1/20th as many.

Medal of Honor, Navy Cross, or whatever military medals are made up by the rich and powerful, of which their sons and daughters absent from any front line duties.
Medals given to people who died from the ill-conceived Iraq and Afghanistan wars are a propaganda plod to entice the less educated and unemployable youths to join the armed forces.
(get rid of our military industrial complex for a healthier and safer US/world)

As was already stated, combat medals are not won. They are earned. Sgt. Peralta gave his life for his fellow Marines and his country. He won the medal in their eyes. This is a hard call, and I'm not sure how as a parent I would feel in this case. When I read stories such as this I am reminded of the Asian American unit from WW2 the 442nd Infantry Regiment which was one of the highest decorated units of that war (21 Medal of Honor recipients). A lot of the men came from families that were interned, that fact alone makes them heroic.

Too bad the military is not as cautious when calling in an air strike. They spend a lot of time analyzing/denying medal awards, but use 30 as the acceptable number of civilian casualties in an air strike.

What's with all the m.i.a. exposure? Why her? She's been glossing the front end of NYT for a week now. For someone who's violently derogatory (watch her wonderful "Gingers" video, threatening red-headed types), Unless I'm missing something, I'll remain mystified. Save it, don't break it, NYT.

I cannot imagine immigrating to, say, France, where I have spent time as a sojourner, and not making a successful effort to become fluent in the language and sensitive to French attitudes, customs, manners and values. While I can certainly never be French, and will always remain an American, I would strive to honor and support the things about France I admire through simple good behavior and responsible citizenship. Ditto Mexico, Italy, Spain, or any other Western nation whose laws and politics offer hope of social and economic justice and religious tolerance. I would strive to blend in to the extent that I not make the native-born uneasy or confuse them as to my cultural loyalties. Proud to be American, yes, but singing in the native key, and speaking in the same language. This seems antithetical to the attitudes of many Muslim immigrants in places like Dearborn, Michigan, and Minneapolis, Minnesota, and elsewhere, such as in Europe, where a determined and sometimes murderous provincialism prevails behind the nervous chatter of a multicultural chimera. I happen to think that traditional American culture, from Washington State to Florida, and Maine to California and all in between, is pretty much a good thing, for all its occasional silliness and pockets of know-nothing politics. I think that because we have a set of fundamental values, a national credo, and a democratic heritage that works relentlessly against the darker impulses of human nature. So the notion of agreeing to afford the same respect we have for our fundamental Western values, rooted in the Magna Carta, our founding documents, and our legal precedents, to some newcomers' blindered customs and intolerance, is repugnant. Let them who chose to come here embrace our culture, imperfect as it is obviously is, and join the effort to perfect it. Anything less is not citizenship, but more economic parasitism.
When do the lit critics start reviewing comic books?

The "social construct" argument, by which "otherness" does not exist until it is confabulated in a "narrative," is pure ideological rubbish. That is is a slippery slope can be seen by the first reader comment to the article, in which a reader maintains that integration does not exist unless there is intermarriage -- presumably as a norm rather than as an exception.

I have on several occasions commented on what I consider to be the unavoidable implications of innate behavioral predilections favored by evolution, as discussed some months ago in articles published in the "Science Times" section of the New York Times. It seems to me that a frank recognition of "otherness," unvarnished by ideology which would deny its very existence, or at least deny that it constitutes "significant otherness," is innate in every individual. Moreover, as every genetic variation occurred in some discrete population group, at some discrete time and place, and as some of these variations might well be considered improvements (or "upgrades," in computer parlance), it is not unreasonable to suppose that individuals with these genetic variants might be innately disposed to foster them by means of selective breeding.

Could it have anything to do with dishonorable wars?
A late return to moral decisions?
Or...that some veterans of these -long late wars- have demonstrated against the illegal wars they were forced to fight?
That they feel they have debased themselves as well as the people they have debased in the doing of their duties?
Just asking.

It has become a tired cliché to talk of the French banlieues as a kind of no-go zone where a visitor risks his life at any time of the day. This cliché is widely used all over Europe -- and further -- as some sort of exorcism: "Thank god, we don't have the equivalent of French banlieues on our country!". In fact, banlieues are diverse. Their inhabitants have sometimes low incomes and a lot of social problems, but in any case, they are no more (and no less) dangerous than Slotervaart or Kanaleneiland in the Netherlands, or, for that matter, the Bronx in NYC or Peckham in London. They are working-class neighbourhoods where there's no work to be found, hence the social issues.

I don't buy a lot of music, but I have all of MIA. and plan to buy her new one.  Anytime established media comes out and tries to trivialize new artistic efforts, its time to pay attention and disable your preconcepts so you can open up to new perspetives and contribute to the evolution of our culture.  I think many of us watching this oil gusher in the Gulf are feeling the forces of revolution rising up where we need so scream or have someone do it for us.  Its become a metaphore - an architype in my dreams for uncontrollable forces - be they Banksters in NYC, or the earth's high pressure oil, or the sun's solar flares, or our own teenager's unrelenting requests for money and refusal to get serious about growing up.   With homeless and joblessness increasing, revolution will become part of the mainstream, not something we all criticize - pointing to terrorists.   If crime suddenly increased in your neighborhood, wouldn't you think about arming yourself and getting training?  Well this summer there will be more riots as the oppressed and exploited rise up and say they 've had enough.  They will be looking for someone like Maya to find her groove and accurately and loudly express their feelings - to gush forth, relieving the building pressure, releasing the tension and maybe even letting us know we don't have to just let others manipulate this world.  Its ok to fight back, to organize and when faced with a strong military, guerilla warfare is about all you have left - See Red Dawn 1984, but imagine the enemy is here within.  Lets not forget our country started with the Revolutionary war declaring our independence from a tyrannical over taxing Colonial power.  Here in Morristown, where he originally camped, I wonder where our George Washington is today.  I see Maya as one of the earlier more insightful ones trying to convert feelings many of us share into warning shouts to rouse us from our American stupor. She is still young, maturing, trying to sort out the various forces at work around her -  Lets give her and others like her a chance to find herself, her mission, and give voice to what needs to be said.

The whole "system" must change. Medals for death and destruction? The family must carry this burden the rest of their time on the planet."Thou Shall Not Kill?" Maybe someone can enlighten me? Read Mary Tillman's book... Valor? How about Peace?

If the LW was inquiring about not putting her real age in her profile and then somehow perpetuating the lie about her age for the rest of her dating days then the critics may have a case. But the question was about bypassing what the LW thought was an arbitrary filter. (Thirty-five is a very common age cut-off for a lot of people I know--it seems only slightly more generous that the Logan's Run scenario.) She was willing to state her correct age in her profile, right up front--and it wasn't that much of a stretch. The only people who, I think, would go haywire would be those who think we all turn into ogres at 36.

There is a problem: What worth has a medal if such "honor" was forked out falsely as in the case of famous "Jessica". Remember that one? Yes, there was a young soldier who did shoot and fight - but he was not so good for advertising.On the other hand: It has degraded all such "honors".
The other point, of course, would be: What honor is there in Goliath fighting David? These troops in Iraq are, as those in Vietnam were, just excessively armed foreigners with dishonest intents. That does not sound like carrying any 'honor'.
